comment.author: 42160369@N02
comment._content: This is a photo of the Jason Gregory home before it was completely dismantled and floated across the Apalachicola River to Torreya State Park in Liberty County. The home, at one time seized for back taxes by a carpet-bagging tax collector of Calhoun County,  was sold to the Leonard brothers of Calhoun County, then to Neal Land and Timber Company. In the early 1930s (please correct the circa date), Neal Land and Timber Company donated it to the State of Florida. The view is actually of the back of the house (note on the right hand side where the walkway to the kitchen was removed) and the view you first see when walking up to the house at Torreya State Park. Notice all the bricks stacked by this area. Those are from the foundation of the kitchen. The giant old oak tree (there used to be two, one on either side of the house) remains at Ocheesee Landing, but the elements and pavement that goes right up to its base have taken their toll. It was once listed in the Big Tree directory. Torreya State Park remains one of the Panhandle's biggest kept secrets. It is a place where I go periodically to get back on track with my senses.

comment.author: 20361422@N00
comment._content: Oh wow thank you so much gatorfriendly. Thank goodness this house has not been lost! Wonderful history!

comment._content: Thank you gatorfriendly! We were able to match the photo to another in our collection and confirm the identification.

comment._content: I cant blieve I forgot about this pic. I was there when I went out to see askmike. This is a great park . Picture of how it looks when you walk up to it. www.flickr.com/photos/cemetery/3411904432/

comment.author: 80753571@N04
comment._content: this is so cool to see that picture! It's the first one i've ever seen that shows the oak tree, so now i have a much better idea of where it sat at Ocheesee landing. Some good friends of mine go camping every year around the 4th of July and put their camper right under that tree, apparently almost exactly where the back of the house was.
